column1: Corky was one of the artists. A portrait-painter
column3: but he hadn't painted any portraits. He was sitting on the side-lines with a blanket over his shoulders
column4: waiting for a chance to get into the game. You see
column5: the catch about portrait-painting — I've looked into the thing a bit — is that you can't start painting portraits till people come along and ask you to
column6: and they won't come and ask you to until you've painted a lot first. This makes it kind of difficult for a chappie. Corky managed to get along by drawing an occasional picture for the comic papers—he had rather a gift for funny stuff when he got a good idea—and doing bedsteads and chairs and things for the advertisements. His principal source of income
column8: was derived from biting the ear of a rich uncle — one Alexander Worple
column9: who was in the jute business. I'm a bit foggy as to what jute is
column10: but it's apparently something the populace is pretty keen on
column11: for Mr. Worple had made quite an indecently large stack out of it.
